He is widely recognized as one of the most significant contributors to the Islamic revival and Islamic political thought in the 20th century.

Maududi began his religious studies at the age of eight and, in 1920, traveled to India, where he joined a Jamat of the Jamaat-e-Islami. He went on to establish the Jamaat-e-Islami Pakistan in 1941, which became a major political party in the country. His political ideology, named Islamic socialism, aimed to establish an Islamic state governed by the principles of Islamic law.

Maududi wrote extensively, with his most famous works including "The Islamic Way of Life" and "Islam: The Seal of The Prophethood," which has become a standard reference on the subject of Islamic theology. In addition to his scholarly pursuits, Maududi was an eloquent speaker and orator. His speeches, both in Pakistan and abroad, helped shape the discourse on Islamic thought and political Islam.

Maududi passed away on July 22, 1979, but his legacy continues to influence Islamic scholarship, politics, and the ideological landscape of the Muslim world. He is fondly remembered as a visionary, whose teachings have provided guidance for millions of people worldwide, and his efforts in shaping the political direction of the Muslim world are celebrated to this day.
